Award.AwardTitle: Investigation of Nanoscale Thermal Transport Across a Point Constriction In Contact and Within a Sub-10 nm Gap

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Proposal number: 1067441
PI: Keunhan Park

While recently emerging tip-based thermal applications have realized unprecedented quality of nanoscale imaging, data storage, and manufacturing, they have also created strong demands on the fundamental understanding of nanoscale thermal transport across a point constriction with a nanometer scale gap or in contact. The spatial resolution of these technologies is determined by the tip- induced localized temperature distribution. However, direct measurement of nanoscale thermal transport and local temperature distribution on the substrate has not been successful mainly due to (1) poor spatial resolution and sensitivity of currently available thermometers; (2) incapability to precisely control the tip-substrate distance below 10 nm; and (3) the difficulty in the precise temperature control of a highly local source and accurate temperature measurement. Moreover, very few measurement and modeling have considered more than one heat transfer mechanisms together in in-situ environments where real applications take place.

This proposal aims to fundamentally understand nanoscale thermal energy transport across a point constriction and resultant non-uniform heated zone of the substrate. To this end, nanothermometers that have a spatial resolution as small as the tip radius, i.e., 10−50 nm will be fabricated and characterized. The local substrate temperature will be measured with the developed nanothermometer while the cantilever is precisely controlled in its temperature and tip position hovering with a sub-10 nm gap. A multiscale model that includes sub-continuum air conduction, solid conduction at the contact, and near-field radiation will be developed to understand the physics in tip-based thermal applications.

Intellectual Merit: The success of this project will provide the quantitative measurement of nanoscale thermal transport between a heated tip and substrate across a sub-10 nm air gap and in contact, and temperature distribution of extremely localized heated zone near the tip. Proposed nanothermometers will provide a sensing probe size smaller than 50 nm, fabrication and characterization of which will be well recognized in the thermal science and engineering community. Systematic approaches on the sub-10 nm gap control of heated cantilevers will be readily applicable to other AFM-based metrologies and technologies, such as SThM and nanomanufacturing. In addition, numerical modeling of coupled nanoscale thermal transport between the tip and substrate will advance the fundamental understanding of nanoscale heat transfer across a point constriction.

Broader Impacts: The results from the measurements and simulations will fill in a knowledge gap and provide timely support for the further advancement of tip-based thermal applications. The research will provide training opportunities for one graduate student and undergraduate students, many of whom will be recruited from underrepresented group of students. To make synergetic effects in nanoscale educations, inter-institute term projects will be initiated. To encourage K-12 outreach activities, an AFM built with LEGO blocks will be developed and used in the SMILE (Science and Mathematics Investigative Learning Experiences) program at URI. Overall, research and education activities involved in this proposal will enhance scientific and technological understanding while promoting teaching, training, and learning.

POR.DRECONTENT:
While recently emerging tip-based thermal applications have realized unprecedented quality of nanoscale imaging, data storage, and manufacturing, they have also created strong demands on the fundamental understanding of nanoscale thermal transport from a heated tip to a substrate. The objective of this project was to investigate nanoscale thermal transport across a tip-substrate point contact and local temperature distribution around the tip. To accomplish the proposed goal, we have conducted (1) the design, fabrication, and characterization of four-point-probe resistive nanothermometers that have a spatial resolution of ~100 nm; (2) the frequency-dependent electrothermal characterization of a doped Si heated microcantilever using the 3-omega method and the frequency-domain finite element analysis; (3) the development of a high-vacuum scanning thermal microscope that provides a vacuum condition below 10^-6 Torr; (4) the  experimental investigation of local heat transfer between a tip and a substrate; (5) numerical studies of diffusive-ballistic heat conduction using the dissipative particle dynamics and a commercial package; and (6) the investigation of extreme near-field thermal radiation between a tip and a substrate using the finite dipole model. 

The outcomes of the project have provided the following intellectual merit: This project was the first attempt to measure nanoscale thermal transport between a heated tip and a substrate and the temperature distribution of a localized heated area near the tip. The fabricated nanothermometers provide a ~100 nm spatial resolution, exceeding the spatial resolution of previous resistive nanothermometers. The fabrication techniques and characterization method employed for the nanothermometers as well as electrothermal characterization of the heated microcantilever will be well recognized to the thermal science and engineering communities. We also demonstrated that a commercial package can be used with a minimal modification to compute multi-dimensional diffusive-ballistic heat conduction in a sub-continuum domain. A novel model has been developed to overcome the calculation limit of the current point dipole model for the calculation of near-field thermal radiation between a heated tip and a substrate in the extreme near field. Our finite dipole model explains the physics behind the redshift of tip-substrate thermal radiation spectrum when the gap become much smaller than the tip radius. 

This project has also created significant broader impacts on knowledge and society, education, and outreach. The obtained experimental and numerical results of thermal transport in nanometer scale will provide a strong tool to fill in a knowledge gap and provide timely support for the further advancement of tip-based thermal applications. This project has provided training opportunities for a couple of PhD students and undergraduate students. The knowledge achieved from this research has been disseminated through multiple journal publications and presentations in conferences, and more manuscripts are under review and in reparation as a result of the very well experimental setup and the broader knowledge about sub-continuum thermal transport. To advance the nanotechnology education, we have developed a LEGO-AFM package as an educational tool and a low-budget AFM by working with a senior design project team. The LEGO-AFM project has been disseminated through the PI’s group website (http://kpark.mech.utah.edu) for details of assembly and operations and has been adopted in outreach and educational activities, such as Nanotechnology Day at Boston University and EGR 450X: Nano Tools course at the University of Rhode Island. Overall, research and education activities involved in this project will enhance scientific and technological understanding while promoting teaching, training, and learning.
